newsitem.title: USA: 3Com/U.S. Robotics to lay off about 800.
newsitem.headline: 3Com/U.S. Robotics to lay off about 800.

text.p: Networking company 3Com Corp, which recently acquired modem maker U.S. Robotics Corp, said Monday it will likely lay off about 800 people over the next year as a result of the merger.

3Com spokeswoman Sara Powers said the company will take charges associated with the layoffs but said the amount has yet to be determined. The charges will be covered in a special merger provision to be recorded in August, so all associated charges will be taken in the current fiscal first quarter which began June 1, she said.
Of the 800 layoffs, 600 are permanent positions and 200 are temporary, Powers said.
She said the permanent positions to be cut total about four percent of the combined 3Com's 13,500 employees. 3Com chief executive Eric Benhamou told employees of the job cuts on July 1, she said.
"They're still trying to redeploy people, so he's estimating that (800 layoffs) over the next year," Powers said. "There are different task teams analyzing how to incorporate the two companies."
A number of top U.S. Robotics executives based in the Chicago area have already announced they are leaving the company, Powers said.

Chief financial officer Mark Remissong, executive vice president of development and corporate strategy Jonathan Zakin, corporate treasurer David Hall, human resources head Elizabeth Ryan, and vice president of the cable business unit Semir Serazi have all said they will pursue other opportunities, Powers said.
A formal announcement on the job cuts will be made either late this month or in early August, she said.
Skokie, Ill.-based U.S. Robotics and 3Com, of Santa Clara, Calif., agreed to merge in February, and last month closed the deal valued at $8.5 billion.
